title: Big Snowstorm Causes Travel Trouble in Chicago
summary: A big winter storm hit Chicago and other places after Thanksgiving, causing lots of problems for travelers. Many flights were delayed or canceled at airports like O'Hare in Chicago and Detroit Metro Airport. The storm brought heavy snow, with Chicago setting a record for November snowfall. People in Wisconsin lost power because of the snow, and churches in Michigan told people to stay home. Planes had to be de-iced to fly safely. The National Weather Service warned about dangerous travel conditions in Iowa and Illinois. This storm made it hard for people to get home after the holiday.

background_read: Thanksgiving is a holiday in the U.S. when families gather, and many people travel. Winter storms can bring snow and ice, making roads and airports dangerous. Airports like O'Hare in Chicago are busy places where planes take off and land. When flights are delayed or canceled, travelers have to wait or find other ways to get home. Power outages happen when snow breaks power lines, leaving homes without electricity. This article talks about how a storm after Thanksgiving caused problems for travelers and others in the Midwest and Northeast.
Article_Structure: WHO: Travelers, airport workers, utility crews, and people in the Midwest and Northeast.
WHAT: A winter storm caused flight delays, cancellations, power outages, and travel hazards.
WHERE: Chicago, Wisconsin, Michigan, Iowa, Illinois, and other areas in the Great Lakes and Northeast.
WHY: The storm brought heavy snow and ice, making travel dangerous and disrupting services after Thanksgiving.

perspectives.description: People trying to get home after Thanksgiving faced delays and cancellations, making their trips stressful.
Workers had to clear snow, de-ice planes, and restore power to help people stay safe.
People in affected areas dealt with power outages and were advised to stay home for safety.
